Fig. 1 HDS conversion of 4,6-DMDBT in model diesel over sulfided catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW and the commercial catalyst CoNiMoW/Al2O3. Fig. 2 HDS conversion of 4,6-DMDBT on catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW (from NiAlMoW to NiZnMoW) as a function of different Zn/Al molar ratio. Fig. 3 XRD patterns of catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW: (a) LDH/LHS precursors of catalysts, (b) catalysts after drying, (c) catalysts after sulfurization. Fig. 4 Pore size distributions of catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW oxide precursors. Fig. 5 EDX spectrum of a large region of a TEM grid of catalysts: (a) NiZn0.63AlMoWS, (b) and (c) NiZn1.88AlMoWS (The Cu peak is due to the TEM grid.). Fig. 6 X-Ray elemental mapping of Ni, Zn, Al, S, Mo, and W in catalysts: (a) NiZn0.63AlMoWS, (b) NiZn1.88AlMoWS. Fig. 7 SEM images of sulfided catalysts: (a) and (c) NiZn0.63AlMoWS, (b) and (d) NiZn1.88AlMoWS. Fig. 8 Visible Raman spectra of catalysts NixZnyAlyMoW (Raman spectra of ZnS is recorded with UV Raman spectroscopy): (a) catalysts after calcination, (b) catalysts after sulfurization, (c) Ni, Zn, Mo, W oxides, (D) Ni, Zn, Mo, W sulfides. Fig. 9 HRTEM images of sulfided catalysts: (a) and (c) NiZn0.63AlMoWS, (b) and (d) NiZn1.88AlMoWS. Table 1 Kinetic parameters for HDS of 4,6-DMDBT over catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW. Hydrodesulfurization of 4,6-DMDBT on multi-metallic bulk catalyst NiAlZnMoW: Effect of Zn Yandie Chen a b Lu Wang a Xinyi Liu a Tiefeng Liu a Baokun Huang a Ping Li a Zongxuan Jiang a ⁎ Can Li a 1 ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, 457 Zhongshan Road, Dalian 116023, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences 457 Zhongshan Road Dalian 116023 China b Graduate University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China Graduate University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 411 84379070; fax: +86 411 84694447. 1 http://www.canli.dicp.ac.cn. Graphical abstract Multi-metallic bulk HDS catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW with different Zn/Al molar ratio were prepared using a NiZnAl-layered hydroxide precursor by co-precipitation method. XRD, HRTEM, and SEM results show that the catalysts possess layered structure, and the layered precursor NixZnyAlz-LDH is a mixture of ZnAl-LDH and NiAl-LDH. Ni(Zn)-promoted Mo(W) active species Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S are detected by Raman spectroscopy and HRTEM. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) result of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) shows that catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW exhibit excellent HDS performance and the sulfur content in the model diesel could be reduced from 517ppm to less than 10ppm (under mild reaction conditions of 3.0MPa of H2 pressure, 300°C, LHSV of 9h−1, and H2/oil ratio of 800Ncm3/cm3). Catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW show higher HDS activity than the commercial catalyst CoNiMoW/Al2O3 due to the high active metal content, the layered structure, and the positive promoter effect of Zn. Besides, Zn-doping also reduces the apparent activation energy of catalysts and results in larger pore volume and larger pore size for catalysts. Part of Zn (Ni) acts as a promoter but other part as a support. The promoter effect of Zn is partially responsible for the high HDS activity. It is found that the second promoter Zn decreases the interaction between alumina and active components Ni, Mo, W to form more Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S active species. Keywords Layered structure 4,6-Dimethyldibenzothiophene Hydrodesulfurization Multi-metallic bulk catalyst Promoter effect 1 Introduction Limiting sulfur contents in fuel oils to ultra-low level has been receiving much more attention due to more stringent environmental regulations and increasing need for clean fuels [1–6]. Hydrodesulfurization is a highly efficient process in refineries. Employing more active catalysts for hydrodesulfurization would be the less costly and the most effective way for the refineries, because it would allow avoiding modifications for the plant installations. And the development of more active ultra-deep HDS catalysts of diesel has been an urgent subject. To obtain ultra low sulfur diesel, it needs to remove the most refractory sulfur-containing compounds such as 4,6-DMDBT [7–13] with low reactivity due to steric hindrance and electronic factors. Currently, multi-metallic bulk catalysts (for example, NEBULA) exhibit superiority for HDS reaction. Since NEBULA bulk catalysts [14,15] were developed and commercialized in 2001, more and more attention has been attracted to develop alternative bulk catalysts with high specific HDS activity [16–19]. However, the application of the bulk catalysts is still limited due to high active metal contents, and so many existing refineries have to use improved classic supported NiMo catalysts. Therefore, to develop inexpensive bulk catalysts with lower active metal contents to compete with the supported catalysts is still an issue. In our previous work, we had employed layered double hydroxide (LDH) and layered hydroxide salts (LHS) as precursors to synthesize a series of multi-metallic bulk catalysts such as NiMoW [7], NiAlMoW [8], and NiZnMoW [20]. The HDS activity of these catalysts was found to be much higher than that of the commercial catalyst CoNiMoW/Al2O3. The catalyst NiMoW with layered structure [20] (76.7wt.% of active metals) could reduce sulfur content of 4,6-DMDBT in model oil from 517 to 6ppm. In order to reduce active metal content, the catalyst NiAlMoW (71.4wt.% of active metals) with inexpensive metal Al was tested and showed much lower HDS activity compared to NiMoW. Why could Al-doping decrease the HDS activity remarkably although a small quantity of Al was doped? Then another metal Zn was introduced into the bulk catalyst NiMoW. We found that the catalyst NiZnMoW (66.3wt.% of active metals) could reduce the sulfur content down to 3ppm from 517ppm under the same reaction conditions. Based on this progress, we further reduce the active metal content by introducing the second promoter Zn [20–24] and Al, and the catalyst NiZnAlMoW can still maintain high HDS activity. The HDS evaluation of 4,6-DMDBT in model oil shows that the NiAlMoW catalyst with Zn-doping could improve the HDS activity. The HDS conversion of the catalyst NiZnAlMoW is 10% higher than that of the commercial catalyst CoNiMoW/Al2O3 under the same condition. The promoter effect of Zn is also discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Zn and Al were added to the catalyst NiMoW based on wt.% of ZnO and Al2O3, while keeping the molar ratio of Ni:Mo:W unchanged. Catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW (x and z were set to be 1, and y was equal to the molar ratio of Zn/Al) were prepared in two steps. Firstly, the LDH or LHS precursors were prepared by the reaction of basic precipitant and mixture solution of Ni2+, Al3+, and Zn2+ with different Zn/Al molar ratio. The precipitate was denoted as NixZnyAlz-LDH. Secondly, catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW were prepared via the reaction of NixZnyAlz-LDH and solution containing MoO4 2− and WO4 2−. The oxide precursors were sulfided and the sulfided catalysts were denoted as NixZny AlzMoWS. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) characterization was performed on a Rigaku D/Max-2500/PC powder diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ =0.154nm). And XRD patterns were collected from 5° to 75° at a speed of 5°min−1 with an operating voltage of 40kV and an operating current of 200mA. The surface area was measured on a NOVA 4200e adsorption analyzer by nitrogen adsorption at −196°C using the BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Teller) method by assuming the section area of nitrogen molecule to be 0.162 nm2 while the pore size distributions were calculated using the BJH (Barrett–Joyner–Hallenda) method with the desorption leg of the isotherms and the pore volume was determined by N2 adsorption at a relative pressure of 0.98. The samples were outgassed in a vacuum (about 10−4 Torr) at 300°C for 6h before adsorption of nitrogen. The morphologies of catalysts were characterized by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). HRTEM images were obtained on a Tecnai G2 F30 S-Twin (FEI Company) instrument equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray analysis system (EDXA) capable of collecting EDS-scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) data and EDS-STEM maps, and SEM images were obtained on a Hitachi S-5500 instrument. Visible Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw inVia Raman microscope and 532nm single-frequency laser was used as the exciting source. UV Raman spectra were recorded on a home-assembled UV Raman spectrograph using a Jobin-Yvon T64000 triplestage spectrograph with spectral resolution of 2cm−1. The laser line at 325nm of a He-Cd laser was used as exciting source with an output of 50mW. Elemental analysis of metal contents was conducted on a Magix-2424 X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectrometer. 2.3 Catalytic activity test The HDS reaction of 4,6-DMDBT was performed on a continuous flow, fixed-bed stainless-steel micro-reactor. A catalyst sample of 0.5g with size 0.4-0.8mm was sulfided under H2S/H2 (10%, v/v) atmosphere at 400°C for 2h prior to the HDS reaction. After the sulfurization, the feed (4,6-DMDBT in decalin with sulfur content of 517ppm) was pumped into the reactor, and the catalytic reaction was carried out at 300°C, 3.0MPa of H2 pressure, a LHSV of 9h−1, and H2/oil ratio of 800Ncm3/cm3. A commercial catalyst CoNiMoW/Al2O3 from SINOPEC was used as the reference catalyst. The product sampling and sulfur contents analysis, a set of experiments performed to check the absence of diffusion limitations, kinetic parameters determination, and apparent activation energy calculation were the same as our previous publications [20]. The overall rate constant and apparent activation energy were obtained from the experimental data based on pseudo-first-order kinetics under the conversions of 4,6-DMDBT lower than 20% on the basis of adjusting LHSV to 15, 18, 20, 22 and 25h−1, respectively, at different temperature of 220, 240, 260, and 280°C, as presented in our previous work [20]. The total sulfur content was determined using Antek 9000S total sulfur analyzer with a detection limit of 0.1mg/L. Furthermore, the sulfur removal of 4,6-DMDBT was calculated according to Eq. (1), where S f and S p are the concentrations of sulfur in the feed and the product, respectively. (1) Sulfur removal = ( 1 − S p / S f ) * 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 HDS activity evaluation and kinetic parameters determination Fig. 1 shows the results of the HDS conversion of 4,6-DMDBT over catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW (NiZnMoW, NiZn1.88AlMoW, NiZn0.63AlMoW, NiZn0.21AlMoW, and NiAlMoW) and the commercial catalyst CoNiMoW/Al2O3. The catalyst NixZnyAlzMoW exhibits higher activity in sulfur removal and the HDS activity of catalysts increases in the order of NiZnMoW≈NiZn1.88AlMoW≈NiZn0.63AlMoW>NiZn0.21AlMoW>NiAlMoW>CoNiMoW/Al2O3. From Fig. 1 it is found that appropriate Zn/Al molar ratio of catalysts can lead to the higher sulfur removal (98%). Compared to the commercial catalyst, all the bulk catalysts could remove sulfur content from 517ppm to less than 8ppm, exhibiting excellent HDS performance. Fig. 2 lists HDS conversion of 4,6-DMDBT over catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW (from NiAlMoW to NiZnMoW) changing as a function of Zn/Al molar ratio. Combining Fig. 1 with Fig. 2, when Zn/Al molar ratio is more than or equal to 0.21, all the catalysts exhibit high HDS activity. NiAlMoWS without Zn presents relatively low HDS activity compared to the catalyst NixZnyAlzMoWS with Zn. This implies that Zn does have promoter effect on HDS reaction. However, the catalyst NiAlMoW still exhibits higher HDS activity than the commercial catalyst probably due to high metal contents and its layered structure [8]. And NiZnMoWS without Al presents similar high HDS activity to NixZnyAlzMoWS catalysts with Al, suggesting that Al also plays a part in dispersing active metals. Table 1 shows kinetic parameters of HDS reaction for 4,6-DMDBT over NiAlMoW, NiZn0.21AlMoW, NiZn0.63AlMoW and the commercial catalyst. The apparent activation energy of catalysts increases in the order of NiZn0.63AlMoW<NiZn0.21AlMoW<NiAlMoW<CoNiMoW/Al2O3, while the over rate constant at the same temperature of catalysts increases according to the following: CoNiMoW/Al2O3 <NiAlMoW<NiZn0.21AlMoW<NiZn0.63AlMoW. It is clear that after Zn-doping, the sulfided catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW show higher HDS activity and lower apparent activation energy than the commercial catalyst and NiAlMoW. 3.2 Textural properties and structure effect The X-ray diffraction patterns of catalyst precursors LDH/LHS, catalysts after drying and sulfurization are presented in Fig. 3 . In Fig. 3a all the precursors of catalysts almost exhibit the same diffraction peaks at about 2θ =13°, 23°, 34°, and 60°, and the diffraction peaks are similar to those of NiAlMoW and NiZnMoW precursors with layered structure [8,20]. This indicates that the layered precursors are synthesized successfully. The peaks below 2θ =30° are related to the basal spacing, and the other peaks correspond to the intermetallic distance within the brucite-like sheets [25]. The two broad peaks (at 2θ =34°, 60°), which are characteristics of a turbostratic structure along hydroxide layer planes [20] also further prove that catalyst precursors possess layered structure. From NiAl-LDH to NiZn-LHS with increasing Zn content, peaks at 11°, 36°, and 62° shift to 13°, 34°, and 60°, respectively. The shift of peaks suggests that LDH and LHS own different cell parameters and different interlamellar organization, because the layer is formed by partial substitution of Al3+ for Ni2+ in octahedral sites in NiAl-LDH. While in NiZn-LHS, in hydroxide layer planes one quarter of octahedral sites are vacant and two Zn2+ cations tetrahedrally coordinated are stabilized just below and above one empty octahedral site to form the layer [26]. After ion-exchanged reaction (Fig. 3b), peaks at 13° shift to low angle at 8°–10° and from 23° to 18°–19°. The shift to lower angle suggests that the basal spacing increases. The increasing basal spacing reveals that MoO4 2− and WO4 2− are exchanged into interlayers successfully. The unshifted peaks at 2θ =34° and 60° suggest that the layered structure is well preserved in catalysts [8]. Fig. 3c shows the XRD patterns of sulfided catalysts and the main composition of catalysts include MoS2/WS2 (JCPDS 65-0160, 08-0237), Ni3S2 (JCPDS 44-1418) and ZnS (JCPDS 36-1450). All the sulfided catalysts display common peaks at 2θ =34° and 60°, which manifests that catalysts still maintain a turbostratic structure after sulfurization. After adding Zn, the peak intensity of Ni3S2, ZnS, and (Mo)WS2 increases with an increase of Zn content, which means larger crystal size of Ni3S2, ZnS, and (Mo)WS2. Because Zn has higher reactivity with Al2O3 to form ZnAl2O4, decreases the formation of inactive Co(Ni)Al2O4 [21–24] and higher Ni content would also inhibit the formation of Al2(MoO4)3 and Al2(WO4)3 [27], the stronger peak intensity of Ni3S2, ZnS, and (Mo)WS2 also means less formation of inactive NiAl2O4, Al2(MoO4)3, and Al2(WO4)3 which are not sulfided easily. Linares et al. [28,29] also reported that Zn increased the ratio between octahedral and tetrahedral Mo in ZnMo/γ-Al2O3 and ZnNiMo/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, for Zn could easily occupy the tetrahedral sites of alumina hindering Ni and Mo to go to these kind of sites. They concluded that there existed a synergetic effect between Ni and Zn. On the whole, the addition of Zn would decrease the interaction between alumina and active components Ni, Mo, and W, leading to form more Ni-promoted Mo(W)–S active species. Delmon and co-workers had proposed remote control model [30–33] that on hydrotreating catalysts spillover hydrogen Hso could create or modify the active sites in the HYD and DDS flowing from promoters (donor) to active phase (acceptor), the existence of Co9S8 which plays an important role in HDS reaction favors HDS reaction and remote control occurs between Co9S8 and MoS2, WS2 and Co–Mo–S phase. In addition, Villarroel et al. [34] had also studied the promotion effect of Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn where they found that the molecule H2 could be dissociated into Hso over sulfided Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, or Zn, and Co, Ni exhibit the maximum promoting activity in HDS reaction. They also concluded that a synergism occurred in HDS reaction between Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, or Zn sulfides and sulfided Mo or W. Considering the discussion above, we conclude that the co-promoters Ni3S2 and ZnS could promote HDS reaction by generating more Hso to create or modify more active sites in HDS reaction. The specific surface area, pore volume and average pore size of calcined catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW are listed in Table 2 . The results show a great increase of both total pore volume and average pore size compared with NiAlMoW. And the surface area increases on the whole from 117 to 128m2/g. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 4 , from NiAlMoW to NiZnMoW the pore size distributes center at about 3-6nm. The pore size distributions of catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW demonstrate that the addition of Zn to NiAlMoW results in larger pore size. Larger pore size and larger pore volume have an positive effect on high HDS activity of catalysts [20,35], because they are beneficial to the diffusion of 4,6-DMDBT into the pores for its steric hindrance during HDS reaction. Table 3 lists the elemental analysis of prepared catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW, and it can be found that the actual Zn/Al molar ratio is close to the calculated value. It is also observed that catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW contain higher active metal content than the commercial catalyst. Considering different content of active metal from 76.7wt.% in catalyst NiMoW [20] to 68.9wt.% in catalyst NiZn0.63AlMoW, it can be seen that catalysts possessing higher active metal contents is not the sole reason for the high HDS activity. The layered structure of catalysts also contributes to the high HDS activity [8,20] for dispersing and distributing sulfided Mo(W) species. Thus the Mo(W) species would contact with Ni or Zn sulfides preferably to form Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S active species. In comparison with catalyst NiMoW, addition of Zn and Al also lowers the active metal content while catalysts still retain high HDS activity. 3.3 Zn effect EDX analysis can be employed to analyze element dispersible uniformity and composition of catalysts. The elements distribution and dispersion for NiZn0.63AlMoWS and NiZn1.88AlMoWS can be seen in Fig. 5 . As observed from the EDX in Fig. 5a–c, there exist all the elements (including Ni, Zn, Al, S, Mo, and W) in catalysts NiZn0.63AlMoWS and NiZn1.88AlMoWS. A larger crystallite of sulfided Ni (Ni3S2) could also be seen clearly in catalyst NiZn1.88AlMoWS, and the Ni3S2 contacts well with the Ni, Zn, Mo and W sulfides. But the Ni, Zn, Mo, and W sulfides disperse unevenly on the sulfided Ni. The EDX analysis of large areas of the HRTEM grid suggests that NiZn0.63AlMoWS and NiZn1.88AlMoWS are composed of sulfided Ni, Zn, Mo and W, alumina and a part of Ni(Zn) in the form of Ni3S2 (ZnS). Further insight into the element composition and distribution in sulfided catalysts is obtained by EDXA elemental mapping as shown in Fig. 6 . Elements Al, S, Mo, and W could disperse well in the whole selected region. However, most of Zn and Ni could not aggregate in the same area but distributes separately. The phase-separation phenomenon implies that Zn could not replace Ni easily in the lattice. Consequently, Ni and Zn will form LDH layered structure with Al, respectively, and the layered precursor is a mixture of ZnAl-LDH and NiAl-LDH. SEM is used to characterize the morphologies of sulfided catalysts as shown in Fig. 7 , where layered structure of sulfided catalysts consisting of many irregular-stacking sheets is observed clearly. Nanoparticles and larger Ni3S2 particles distributing on the surface and galleries of the layered catalysts could be observed clearly, too. Fig. 7 displays that NixZnyAlyMoW catalysts still maintain layered structure after sulfurization. The result is in line with that from XRD result of sulfided catalysts. Considering the preparation process of catalysts, one could assign the particles on the surface mainly to Mo, W, and MoW composite species, while the layer sheet is the host layer of ZnAl-LDH and NiAl-LDH. Combined Fig. 7 with Fig. 5 and Fig. 6, it is confirmed that Ni3S2/ZnS behaves as the support, and the Mo and W sulfided particles are deposited on the surface and the interlayer galleries in the catalysts. Raman spectroscopy is an effective tool in detecting species on the surface of catalysts. The visible Raman spectra of oxide and sulfided catalysts NixZnyAlyMoW are displayed in Fig. 8a and Fig. 8b, respectively. In order to further identify peaks of catalysts, separate oxides and sulfides of Ni, Zn, Mo, and W are also characterized by Raman spectra as presented in Fig. 8c and Fig. 8d, respectively. Because of strong fluorescence interference of ZnS, the UV Raman spectroscopy is used. In Fig. 8a, for oxide catalysts NixZnyAlyMoW, the bands at 388, 532cm−1, and a broad band (from 650 to 1000cm−1) are observed. According to peaks of separate oxide Ni, Zn, Mo, and W in Fig. 8c, the bands at 388cm−1 are mainly attributed to MoO3, the bands at 532cm−1 are mainly assigned to NiO, and composite oxides of Ni, Mo, and W. And the broad band are associated with MoO3, WO3, and composite oxides of Ni, Mo, and W [36–39]. Besides, in Fig. 8a, with the increasing amount of Zn, the broad band shifts to lower wave numbers and finally a single overlapping band is formed. In the meantime, the intensity of other bands also increases. This indicates that adding Zn would favor the surface Ni, Mo, and W species to aggregate to form some new composite species. In Fig. 8b, for catalysts NixZnyAlyMoWS, the band intensity increases more obviously with an increase of Zn, and there only appear bands at 240, 300, 353, 380, and 413cm−1. According to the peaks of separate sulfides of Ni, Zn, Mo, and W in Fig. 8d, the bands at 240cm−1 are assigned to WS2, the bands at 300cm−1 are assigned to Ni3S2, the bands at 353cm−1 are associated with ZnS and WS2, and the bands at 380cm−1 are associated with MoS2 and Ni3S2. In Fig. 8b for all the sulfided catalysts, a new band around 413cm−1 is detected. In Fig. 8d, NiWS has similar bands at 351 and 420cm−1 to that of WS2, NiMoS has similar bands at 378 and 404cm−1 to that of MoS2, and NiZn0.63AlMoWS own similar bands at 353, 380, and 413cm−1 to that of both WS2 and MoS2. From Fig. 8d, it is observed that the band of NiZn0.63AlMoWS at 413cm−1 is not an overlap band of bands at 404 and 420cm−1. Moreover, in visible Raman spectra of catalyst ZnMoWS [20], there also existed only the band at 413cm−1 and no bands were detected at 404 and 420cm−1. So it is definite that in Fig. 8b the band at 413cm−1 is connected with composite species Mo–W–S. The sulfided Mo(W) composite species could interact with Ni(Zn) sulfides to form Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S active species and the special composite species could promote the HDS reaction. Band intensity increasing with an increase of Zn content further evidences an increase of surface species Ni, Mo, W concentration. And this means that addition of Zn inhibits the interaction between alumina and active components Ni, Mo, and W, so that more surface Ni, Zn, Mo, and W species would form composite species. 3.4 Active species dispersion and distribution It has been generally accepted that hydrogenation performance is related to the stacking layer number of WS2 or MoS2 slabs. The unsupported sulfided catalysts with higher stacking layers are beneficial to the improvement of hydrogenation performance and formation of type II Ni–Mo(W)–S active phase [40–45]. So as to further study the influence of the morphologies on the HDS activity and to confirm the active composite species, HRTEM is used to characterize the morphologies of catalysts (Fig. 9 ). The grain size of sulfided catalysts is about 11-23nm. The average slab length and the stacking degree of WS2 or MoS2 are about 3-14nm and 3-7 layers, respectively. Crystalline lattice fringes of ZnS, Ni3S2, WS2, and MoS2 can be distinguished clearly. As observed in Fig. 9, the ZnS and Ni3S2 are covered by curved slabs of WS2/MoS2 with a basal spacing of 6.16Å. Composite sulfided species, which consist of mixed Ni, Mo, and W sulfided species could also be observed distinctly. Separate lattice fringes of Ni and Zn sulfides show that most of Ni and Zn would not aggregate in the same place, but still contacts with Mo, W to form composite species, respectively. This result is in accordance with the elemental mapping result from Fig. 6. Irregularly stacking sheets in HRTEM images further prove that sulfided catalysts possess layered structure. Then, on the basis of the results from XRD, SEM, and HRTEM, the model of the catalysts NixZnyAlyMoW and the processes for the formation of sulfided catalysts can be proposed. LDH/LHS precursor with multi-layers is used as a structural template to prepare the catalyst, which also retains the layered structure. After sulfurization, the layered Ni3S2/ZnS behaves as the support, and Mo(W) sulfides are deposited on the surface and interlayer galleries, leading to formation of Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S active species. High stacking layers observed in catalysts would also facilitate the formation of more Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S active species to improve HDS activity. 4 Conclusion In summary, a multi-metallic bulk catalyst NixZnyAlzMoW with layered structure exhibits excellent HDS performance. The main active species of catalysts are composite sulfided species of Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S. The higher HDS activity of catalysts NixZnyAlzMoWS than that of the commercial catalyst is ascribed to the high active metal content, the layered structure and Zn promoter effect. Zn (Ni) could act as a promoter and part of Zn (Ni) as a support. It is found that the second promoter Zn decreases the interaction between alumina and active components Ni, Mo, and W. The layered structure could expose more active sites to form more Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S active species. Besides, Zn-doping also reduces the apparent activation energy of catalysts and results in larger pore volume and larger pore size for the catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Multi-metallic bulk HDS catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW with different Zn/Al molar ratio were prepared using a NiZnAl-layered hydroxide precursor by co-precipitation method. XRD, HRTEM, and SEM results show that the catalysts possess layered structure, and the layered precursor NixZnyAlz-LDH is a mixture of ZnAl-LDH and NiAl-LDH. Ni(Zn)-promoted Mo(W) active species Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S are detected by Raman spectroscopy and HRTEM. Hydrodesulfurization (HDS) result of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) shows that catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW exhibit excellent HDS performance and the sulfur content in the model diesel could be reduced from 517ppm to less than 10ppm (under mild reaction conditions of 3.0MPa of H2 pressure, 300°C, LHSV of 9h−1, and H2/oil ratio of 800Ncm3/cm3). Catalysts NixZnyAlzMoW show higher HDS activity than the commercial catalyst CoNiMoW/Al2O3 due to the high active metal content, the layered structure, and the positive promoter effect of Zn. Besides, Zn-doping also reduces the apparent activation energy of catalysts and results in larger pore volume and larger pore size for catalysts. Part of Zn (Ni) acts as a promoter but other part as a support. The promoter effect of Zn is partially responsible for the high HDS activity. It is found that the second promoter Zn decreases the interaction between alumina and active components Ni, Mo, W to form more Ni(Zn)–Mo(W)–S active species.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodesulfurization of 4,6-DMDBT on multi-metallic bulk catalyst NiAlZnMoW: Effect of Zn
